details.body:
The Courts have established as a clear general principle that the cost of travelling from an employee's home to his or her normal place of work is not travel in the performance of the duties, see [EIM31650](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM31600#EIM31650). The expense merely puts the employee into a position to perform his or her duties. The cases that have established this principle are:
Cook v Knott2TC246
Revell v Directors of Elworthy Bros & Co Ltd3TC12
Andrews v Astley8TC589
Ricketts v Colquhoun10TC118, see [EIM31641](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM31600#EIM31641)
Nolder v Walters15TC380
Burton v Rednall35TC435
Parikh v Sleeman63TC75, see [EIM32360](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32350#EIM32360)
Miners v Atkinson68TC629, see [EIM32380](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32350#EIM32380)
Kirkwood v Evans74TC481, see [EIM32374](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32350#EIM32374)
The only exceptions to this rule are: * travel from home to a temporary workplace, see [EIM32000](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32000) * where the employee has a travelling appointment, see [EIM32366](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32350#EIM32366) * where the employee’s home is a place of work **and** the place where the employee lives is dictated by the requirements of the job, see [EIM32370](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32350#EIM32370) * where the duties of the employment are carried out wholly or partly outside the UK, see [EIM34020](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM34000#EIM34020) * where a non-domiciled employee is working in the UK, see [EIM35030](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM35000#EIM35030) * emergency call-outs see [EIM32386](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32350#EIM32386).
